parts.text: Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain the baseball event code '7/F7LD'.
Sure! '7/F7LD' means a fly ball to left field, with the batter being put out as a result of a line drive that is caught. This is a standard fly out, where the left fielder made the putout.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What about 'D8/L89XD+'?
'D8/L89XD+' signifies a double to centerfield, where the play is considered a line drive. 'XD+' indicates that the ball was hit into a particular spot in the outfield.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Can you explain '13/G1S'?
'13/G1S' means a ground ball to the pitcher which resulted in a single for the batter.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does K mean?
'K' indicates a strikeout. The batter has been called out after accumulating three strikes.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
And what does 'W' signify?
'W' signifies a walk, where the batter advances to first base after the pitcher has thrown four balls.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'HR/F78XD.1-H' mean?
'HR/F78XD.1-H' denotes a home run that was a fly ball to center-right field, including a line drive type out in the outfield. The '1-H' signifies that a runner on first was able to score on the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
And 'E6/TH/G6+.B-1'?
'E6/TH/G6+.B-1' represents an error by the shortstop, where the error occurred on the throw on a ground ball. The .B-1 signifies that the runner advanced to first because of the error.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain '8/L8D'.
'8/L8D' signifies a line drive to center field that is a double. The double is the result of a line drive that landed in the outfield.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '8/F8' mean?
'8/F8' means the batter is out on a fly ball to center field. The ball was caught, resulting in an out.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
And 'S9/L9'?
'S9/L9' represents a single, hit to right field via a line drive. A single means the batter has safely made it to first base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What about '486(1)/FO/F8S.B-1'?

'486(1)/FO/F8S.B-1' means the batter grounded out to second, with the shortstop making the putout on a force out. It is also a fly ball to center field where the batter reached first due to the force out. The B-1 represents the fact that the batter reached first base on the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is '9/F9S'?
'9/F9S' signifies a fly ball to right field that results in a putout. The batter has hit a standard fly ball that was caught for the out.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain '4/F89S'.

'4/F89S' indicates that the batter hit a fly ball into the center-right field area, and the ball was caught for an out. It is a standard fly out, with the player making the putout being the right fielder.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '53/G56S.1-2' mean?
'53/G56S.1-2' means the batter hit a ground ball to the third baseman, resulting in an out. The 1-2 represents that a runner on first advanced to second.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain '3/G3+'.
'3/G3+' signifies a ground ball to the first baseman resulting in an out. The + on the end means that the put out is made by stepping on first base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is '63/G6M-'?

'63/G6M-' means the batter hit a ground ball to the shortstop, and the shortstop threw to first, resulting in an out at first base. The 'M-' denotes the play is a ground out, not involving other bases.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
And what is '53/G5'?
'53/G5' signifies a ground ball to third base, resulting in an out at first. The play resulted in a put out for the batter at first base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What about '13/G34S'?
'13/G34S' means the batter hit a ground ball to the pitcher who threw to the first baseman for the out. The S on the end signifies that the batter reached first base safely as a result of this play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is '6/P6D'?
'6/P6D' means the batter was out on a pop fly to shortstop, and the shortstop made the putout by catching the ball. The play is considered to be a pop fly.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
'5/P56' means the batter hit a pop fly to third base, and the shortstop made the putout by catching the ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'S9/G34+' mean?
'S9/G34+' represents a single to right field that was a ground ball to first with the batter reaching first base. The '34+' signifies that the first baseman made the put out by touching first base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '64(1)/FO/G6M.B-1' signify?

'64(1)/FO/G6M.B-1' means a ground out in which the batter hit the ball to shortstop who threw to first. The .B-1 signifies that the batter reaches first base. The G6M signifies a routine ground out by shortstop to first.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain the event 'WP.1-2'.
'WP.1-2' denotes a wild pitch, which allowed the runner on first to advance to second.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '43/G4' mean?
'43/G4' signifies a ground out to second base, and the first baseman makes the putout.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain the event 'S7/L7+'.
'S7/L7+' represents a single, which was hit as a line drive to left field.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
'S7/L7D+.1-2' signifies a single to left field that was a line drive which ended up being a double. A runner on first has advanced to second as well.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '8/L8XD+' mean?
'8/L8XD+' signifies a line drive to center field that results in a put out. The 'XD+' signifies that the ball was hit to a specific area of the outfield. The putout was made by the centerfielder.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What about 'W.2-3;1-2'?
'W.2-3;1-2' represents a walk, and the result of that walk is a runner on second moving to third and a runner on first moving to second.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.

'46(1)/FO/G34.3-H;2-3;B-1' means a ground ball to second base, who threw to the shortstop for the force out, resulting in a ground out. The 3-H, 2-3;B-1 represents runners on 3rd scoring, a runner on second advancing to third, and batter going to first. 'FO' indicates that it was a force out.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'CSH(242536)' mean?
'CSH(242536)' means caught stealing by the catcher at second. The (242536) is the sequence of the play. The catcher fielded the ball at home and made the putout at second.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'SB2.1-3(E2/TH)' mean?

'SB2.1-3(E2/TH)' signifies a stolen base at second, and a runner on first advanced to third. The error is recorded as an error to the catcher, and the 'TH' signifies that the catcher made a throw to try to prevent the runner from stealing.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'S1/BG23.3-H(UR);1-2'?
'S1/BG23.3-H(UR);1-2' signifies a single to the pitcher and a ground out by the pitcher to first or second base, with a run from third scoring unearned. A runner on first advances to second.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '4(1)3/GDP/G4' mean?

'4(1)3/GDP/G4' means a double play ground out where a runner was tagged out at second by the second baseman who throws to the first baseman at first base, resulting in a ground out.  The G4 indicates a ground out to second who then makes a putout at first.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'S8/F8S'?
'S8/F8S' means a single, which was hit as a fly ball to center field. The 'S' indicates that the batter reached first base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does '54(1)/FO/G56.B-1' mean?

'54(1)/FO/G56.B-1' signifies a force out at second base that originated from the third baseman and ended with the shortstop.  The B-1 indicates that the batter reached first safely as a result of the force out play.  The G56 represents a ground out by the third baseman to the shortstop.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
'S9/G34.1-2' is a single hit to right field, which then resulted in a ground out from first to second. The runner on first base advanced to second as well.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'K+PB.1-2' mean?
'K+PB.1-2' represents a strikeout, and that a runner on first advances to second base as a result of a passed ball on the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Tell me about the 'E$' event.
The 'E$' event code represents an error by a fielder. It's used when a fielder's misplay enables a batter or baserunner to advance or reach base when they otherwise would not have.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
And what is the 'FLE$' event?
The 'FLE$' event refers to an error that happens when a fielder mishandles a foul fly ball. It indicates a specific type of error on a foul ball that allows the batter to continue to have an at bat.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'NP' mean in a baseball play-by-play feed?

The 'NP' event code, meaning 'no play', is often used to indicate when substitutions are made during a baseball game. It essentially serves as a marker to denote a change in personnel and isn't directly related to the action of play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Explain the difference between 'I' and 'IW'?
Both 'I' and 'IW' denote an intentional walk. They both indicate that a pitcher has intentionally walked a batter by throwing balls out of the strike zone. They are typically used interchangeably.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
Tell me about the difference between 'W' and 'IW+event'?

The event code 'W' simply means the batter was walked due to the pitcher throwing four balls, and the batter advances to first base. 'IW+event' represents an intentional walk, after which another action by a runner takes place. The runner may advance on the play, or a substitution may be made after the intentional walk.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is a 'LDP' in baseball?
'LDP' represents a 'lined into double play'. It indicates that a batter hit a line drive that was caught by a fielder and resulted in two outs in a single play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'GDP' mean in baseball?
'GDP' stands for 'grounded into double play'. It refers to a play where a batter hits a ground ball that results in two outs.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is a 'DGR'?

'DGR' means 'ground rule double'. This occurs when a ball is hit in such a way that it bounces into a foul area, out of play, or into a designated area within the playing field as defined by the rules of the field itself. In this circumstance, the runner is awarded second base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'TH' mean in a baseball event?
The modifier 'TH' signifies a throw. It is usually placed on an error or stolen base event to show that a throw was involved on the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'BP' mean?
The modifier 'BP' indicates that the play involves a bunt that results in a pop up.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'BG' mean?
'BG' indicates a ground ball bunt. It signifies that a bunt was hit as a ground ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is the meaning of a 'BINT' modifier?

The modifier 'BINT' indicates a 'batter interference'. It usually means that the batter is called out due to offensive interference. It represents a penalty against a batter who interferes with the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'BL' mean in baseball plays?
'BL' means a line drive bunt. It signifies a bunt that is hit on a line.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'BOOT' mean?
The modifier 'BOOT' indicates that a 'batter is batting out of turn'. It indicates a violation of the lineup rule, and can lead to an out.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'BPDP'?
The modifier 'BPDP' means the batter bunted into a double play, with the play resulting in a pop up.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'BR' mean in baseball play logs?
'BR' signifies that a runner was hit by a batted ball. It usually means that the runner is called out, and the ball is dead.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'C' signify when listed as a pitch modifier?
When listed as a pitch modifier, 'C' signifies a 'called strike'. This means that the umpire called a strike on a pitch, where the batter did not attempt to swing at the ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is a 'COUB'?
The code 'COUB' indicates a 'courtesy batter'. The courtesy batter is put in place of a previous batter who needs to be removed.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'COUF'?
'COUF' means a 'courtesy fielder'. This code is used when a player is substituted as a courtesy fielder into a defensive position in the game.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'COUR' mean in a baseball event log?
'COUR' signifies a 'courtesy runner'. This is used to indicate a situation where a runner is substituted onto the base for another player on the team.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'DP' signify?
'DP' is a general term for 'double play'. This modifier can be used on any play that results in a double play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is modifier 'E$'?

The modifier 'E$' represents an error on the particular play indicated by $. The modifier is always used with a base action such as a single, double, force out, etc., to show that a fielder committed an error on a play with that action.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'F' mean?
The modifier 'F' indicates that the play resulted in a fly ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is a 'FDP'?
'FDP' stands for 'fly ball double play'. This indicates that a play where a fly ball was caught resulted in two outs.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'FINT'?
The modifier 'FINT' denotes 'fan interference'. This means that the play was disrupted by a fan physically interfering with the action on the field.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'FL' mean in baseball plays?
'FL' means that the play resulted in a foul ball, and is typically used as a pitch modifier, or to specify a type of foul.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'FO' mean?
The modifier 'FO' indicates that a runner was put out on a force out at a base.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'G' mean?
The modifier 'G' denotes that the play resulted in a ground ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'GDP' mean?
The modifier 'GDP' indicates that a batter grounded into a double play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'GTP' signify?
The modifier 'GTP' signifies a 'ground ball triple play'. This means that a batted ball resulted in a triple play on a ground ball play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is an 'IF'?
'IF' represents 'infield fly rule'. This indicates that the infield fly rule was called.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'INT' mean?

'INT' means 'interference'. This usually means that the batter interfered with a fielder making a play on the ball. See additional modifiers such as 'FINT', 'RINT', and 'BINT' for more specific interferences.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'IPHR' mean?
'IPHR' means 'inside the park home run'. This signifies a home run when the batter touches all the bases and scores without the ball leaving the playing field.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is the 'L' modifier?
The modifier 'L' denotes that a batted ball is a line drive.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'LDP' mean?
The modifier 'LDP' means 'lined into double play'. This indicates that the ball was hit as a line drive that resulted in two outs.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does modifier 'LTP' signify?
The modifier 'LTP' signifies 'lined into triple play'. This means the ball was hit as a line drive that resulted in three outs.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'MREV' mean?
'MREV' indicates a 'manager review', and that the play on the field was challenged by a manager and resulted in an official review of the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'NDP' signify?
The modifier 'NDP' means 'no double play' credited for this play. It signifies a play in which the normal double play may not be awarded due to circumstances of the play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is the 'OBS' modifier?
'OBS' denotes obstruction. It signifies that a fielder impeded a runner's progress while not possessing the ball. The result is often an award of a base to the obstructed player.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'P' mean?
The modifier 'P' indicates that a play resulted in a pop fly.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is the modifier 'PASS'?
'PASS' means a 'runner passed another runner and was called out'. The modifier means that a runner was called out for passing another runner on the bases.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'R$' mean?
'R$' means 'relay throw from the initial fielder to $ with no out made'. It indicates that a relay throw was made to another fielder, but no put out resulted from the throw.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'RINT' stand for?
'RINT' signifies 'runner interference'. It represents a situation in which a base runner is called out for interfering with the play or actions of the fielders.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'SF'?
'SF' indicates a 'sacrifice fly'. This means the batter hit a fly ball which resulted in a putout but also advanced a base runner, scoring a run.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does a modifier 'SH' mean?
'SH' signifies 'sacrifice hit', and is used to represent a sacrifice bunt.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does 'TH' mean in pitch modifiers?
The modifier 'TH' signifies that the pitch was made on a throw to a base after a pitch to a batter.  It is not used if there is no pickoff attempt or play at another base
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is 'TH%'?
'TH%' means 'throw to base %'. It is generally used to mark the throw during pickoff or when a runner attempts to steal.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier 'TP' indicate?
'TP' indicates that the play resulted in a triple play. This means that three runners were put out on a single play.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is modifier 'UINT'?
'UINT' means 'umpire interference'. This occurs when the umpire makes physical contact that disrupts a play, and is generally considered to be a dead ball.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What is the purpose of the modifier 'UREV'?
The modifier 'UREV' indicates 'umpire review of call on the field'. This means that the umpires reviewed the call, and the results were changed or confirmed.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier '+' in the pitch modifier section mean?
The modifier '+' means a pitch was made on a following pickoff throw by the catcher.
Explain baseball event codes and scenarios based on user queries.
What does the modifier '*' mean in baseball pitch...
The modifier '*' signifies a 'swinging strike' on the pitch. This means that the batter attempted to swing at the pitch and missed.
